Copyright 2025 NewsRx, LLC All Rights Reserved Section: SUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH Length: 659 words Body 2025 MAY 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- New research on Sustainability Research is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Washington, District of Columbia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "A better understanding of youth as autonomous consumers in the food market is needed to guide food and nutrition policies to achieve healthier and sustainable diets because they interact with the food environment to obtain, prepare, and consume food and beverages. Compared to other age groups, evidence on children and adolescents (youth) purchasing behavior and front-of-package (FOP) labeling is limited." Financial supporters for this research include Comision Nacional de Investigacion Cientifica y Tecnologica (CONICYT), Centro de Investigacion en Alimentos para el Bienestar en el Ciclo Vital (ABCvital) , INTA, Universidad de Chile, Becas Don Carlos Antonio Lopez Doctorado 2017, the Toward Sustainability Foundation of Concord, Massachusetts, USA, Research program on Innovative Methods and Metrics for Agriculture, Nutrition and Health Actions (IMMANA) - UK Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO), Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from International Food Policy Research Institute, "The objective of the study was to assess youth's purchasing behavior by conducting an online discrete choice experiment (DCE) in Santiago, Chile. We assessed four different food attributes: price, FOP nutrition warning label, FOP eco-label, and type of product (i.e., yogurt, cookie, apple). Data were analyzed using mixed logit models complemented with latent class logit models to further explore heterogeneity in preferences. A total of 329 youth aged 10-14 years participated in the study. Our results reveal that youths' purchasing behavior is mostly determined by price, followed by product type and environmental sustainability as measured by the FOP eco-label; responsiveness to price was not moderated by whether the youth received pocket money from a family member regularly. We further identified five classes (groups) of youth consumers where some exhibited preference for health and nutrition attributes, environmental sustainability, or price." According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Our findings provide a better understanding of youth as diverse and autonomous consumers and suggest at least some youths are responsive to labeling interventions." This research has been peer-reviewed. For more information on this research see: Front-of-pack Labels and Young Consumers: an Experimental Investigation of Nutrition and Sustainability Claims In Chile. Food Quality and Preference, 2025;127. Food Quality and Preference can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Food Quality and Preference - www.journals.elsevier.com/food-quality-and-preference/) Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Gabriela Fretes, International Food Policy Research Institute Ifpri, 1201 Eye St NW, Washington, DC 20005, United States. Additional authors for this research include Norbert L. W. Wilson, Camila Corvalan, Christina D. Economos and Sean B. Cash. The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foodqual.2025.105432. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation. Keywords for this news article include: Washington, District of Columbia, United States, North and Central America, Beverage, Diet and Nutrition, Food, Food Markets, Health and Medicine, Sustainability Research, International Food Policy Research Institute. Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC Load-Date: May 30, 2025 End of Document MarketBeat.com
